Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: The lab materials are very helpful, and the course is good and useful. But it is difficult for students to get the ideas of models at the very beginning, probably starting with examples and then introduce ideas will be better.

strength: cover much useful materials. 
weakness: students don't understand some materials.
I suggest professor can provide more effective methods to explain materials to student.
course materials are a little bit confusing.
The topic itself is quite complicated, and if you don't understand the first part you will certainly not understand anything that follows
Maybe try to make the slides easier to understand
It is a good course, but sometimes the explanation is not clear thus quite confusing. The instructor might consider spend more time explaining concepts.
The homework sets are very challenging, but I learned a lot after working through them.

this course is very important for biostatistics students but also a hard one to learn. The course materials are very complete but it just takes time to fully understand. I wish the instructor could explain the formulas more clear in class, and for labs, may focus more on how and why we get the results, and how to interpret the output from the SAS/R program rather than introducing the code step by step.
This course can be a little too math-driven, and so consequently we don't have a strong understanding of the concepts.
The lecture PPT and lab pdf files could be more clear (color, format, font etc.)

It is difficult to evaluate this course because even though the instructor and TA were always available and tried their best to teach well, the material is very dense and students had very different backgrounds. I struggled at times to follow the material, but I received enough support to still do well. My main suggestion would be for the department to create two courses, one with a theoretical focus and one more applied.
She is a very nice instructor, but it would be better if she could provide us with SAS and R code in lab sessions, sometimes it would be time-consuming for us to type all of them ourselves.

strength: explain everything patiently.
weakness: use slides to explain materials, sometimes students can not understand very well. 
I suggest professor can write more notes on blackboard to help students understand some professional concepts.

She clearly tries, but there are mistakes in her powerpoint and overall the lecture powerpoints are not made very well... a lot of mathematical shortcuts that are not explained and new variables introduced that are not explained. The substitute lecturer spent a good 30 minutes explaining background information that we need to know just so we can understand a SINGLE SLIDE
She is very thoughtful but sometimes fail to teach effectively
Ummm, she's like a joke, making mistakes all the time. I don't think she really understands what she's teaching.
I just wonder why she can find a faculty position here.
Hope there is more into details explanations to some terms. Maybe put more examples in the lecture section so that there is a good transition to lab session.
Professor Lin is helpful and patient.
The instructor makes complex concepts much easier to be understood.

Prof. Lin is nice and we can tell she tried very hard to explain the concepts, but sometimes it wasn't very successful. I think it would be great if she could derive the formulas correctly in class and interpret each parameters in details.

Professor Lin was always available to answer questions after class and was very receptive to feedback. She always tried to incorporate feedback into her teaching. For example, when students were struggling with some concepts and we requested more examples, she incorporated more examples into her lectures. I would recommend her, but believe the department should restructure the course.
The course is very useful both in career and research.
This course provide a basic understanding of longitudinal data and multilevel data analysis. It is really helpful for building a research process.
Well, the lecturer next year will be much better. The material is interesting and very important, so I would highly recommend
The course teaches basic longitudinal analysis concepts and corresponding coding skills and I would recommend the course.
The class is challenging but it provides important skillsets necessary for a statistician.

This course provides a theoretical foundation and applications in longitudinal data analysis. I would not recommend this course to students who are not in the Biostatistics program. For those in the program, this course will require many hours of self-study to truly understand the material. I still did learn a lot and would recommend for the department to make this course more focused on applications.
